field.name: Primary Care
field.description: General healthcare delivery, patient care, and primary care physician practices.

problems.title: Critical Shortage of Primary Care Physicians Threatening Healthcare Access
problems.description: The United States faces an escalating shortage of primary care physicians that threatens the foundation of healthcare delivery. Projections indicate a shortage of 68,020 to 87,150 full-time equivalent primary care physicians by 2036-2037. The family medicine specialty alone is projected to meet only 73% of demand by 2037—a 27% shortage. Nearly half of all practicing physicians are over 55 and approaching retirement, while medical students increasingly choose higher-paying specialties over primary care. Lower compensation compared to specialists (primary care physicians earn 40-50% less than procedure-based specialists), combined with increasing administrative burden and burnout, has made primary care an unattractive career choice. The maldistribution of physicians compounds this crisis, with rural and underserved areas experiencing disproportionate shortages. HRSA projects that by 2026, the overall physician workforce will meet only 90% of estimated demand, further eroding to 87% by 2036.
problems.summary: The US faces a projected shortage of 68,000-87,000 primary care physicians by 2036-2037, driven by aging workforce, low compensation relative to specialists, and increasing burnout.

barriers: Long training pipeline (7+ years for physicians)

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Moderate - AAMC, HRSA, AMA actively tracking

rootCauses.description: Medicare GME funding caps frozen since 1996 limit residency training slots
Primary care compensation 40-50% lower than specialists discourages career choice
Aging physician workforce with 50% over age 55 approaching retirement
Medical school debt averaging $200,000+ drives students to higher-paying specialties
Increasing administrative burden reduces job satisfaction

consequences.description: Patients face extended wait times for appointments (average 26 days for new patient)
Increased emergency department utilization for non-emergent conditions
Worsening health outcomes due to delayed preventive care and chronic disease management
Rural hospital closures (768 at risk, 315 at immediate risk)

problems.title: Epidemic of Physician Burnout Driving Primary Care Workforce Attrition
problems.description: Primary care physicians are experiencing unprecedented levels of burnout, creating a workforce crisis that threatens healthcare delivery. Current data shows 67% of surveyed physicians experience burnout and overwork, with more than 300 physicians dying by suicide annually. Nearly half of primary care physicians report burnout, and critically, over one-third of these burned-out physicians plan to stop seeing patients within one to three years. The estimated cost of physician burnout—with one in five physicians leaving the profession—is $4 billion annually. Contributing factors include ever-increasing administrative burdens (physicians complete an average of 43 prior authorization requests weekly), excessive EHR documentation requirements, longer work hours, higher patient volumes, stagnant reimbursement, reduced autonomy, and lack of institutional support. Following the COVID-19 pandemic, these pressures have intensified significantly. The burnout epidemic creates a vicious cycle: as physicians leave, remaining physicians face even heavier workloads, accelerating burnout and further departures.
problems.summary: 67% of physicians experience burnout, with over one-third of burned-out PCPs planning to stop seeing patients within 1-3 years, costing the healthcare system $4 billion annually.

barriers: Systemic healthcare payment model incentivizes volume over value
Cultural stigma around seeking mental health help
Health system financial pressures resist staffing improvements

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Growing - NAM, AMA, medical societies engaged
neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - Dr. Lorna Breen Heroes Foundation funding

Loss of autonomy due to corporate consolidation and insurance restrictions
Moral injury from inability to provide optimal patient care

consequences.description: 1 in 5 physicians leaving profession accelerates workforce shortage
Over 300 physician suicides annually
Decreased quality of patient care from fatigued providers
Reduced patient access as physicians limit hours or retire early

problems.title: Severe Primary Care Access Barriers in Rural and Underserved Communities
problems.description: More than 60 million Americans—approximately one-fifth of the US population—live in rural areas, yet 80% of rural America is classified as medically underserved. More than 40 million rural Americans live in areas with too few primary care providers. Rural residents face multiple compounding barriers to healthcare: higher rates of uninsurance, necessity to travel longer distances for care, severe provider shortages, and limited healthcare infrastructure. These barriers contribute to significantly poorer health outcomes and shorter life expectancies compared to urban populations. The crisis is intensifying as approximately 768 rural hospitals are at risk of closing, with 315 at immediate risk within three years. When rural hospitals close, residents must travel an average of 20 miles farther for common services and 40 miles farther for specialized services. Specific populations face additional challenges: more than half of rural counties lack hospital-based obstetric services, and by 2030, the supply of OB/GYNs is expected to meet only 50% of rural demand. These disparities disproportionately affect Black and American Indian/Alaska Native populations.
problems.summary: 80% of rural America is medically underserved, with 40+ million residents lacking adequate primary care access, 768 rural hospitals at risk of closure, and significantly worse health outcomes.

barriers: Geographic dispersion makes service delivery expensive
Low patient volumes make facilities financially unsustainable
Difficulty recruiting providers to rural areas

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Moderate - HRSA, Rural Health Information Hub active
neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - Various federal rural health programs

Lower reimbursement rates and higher uninsured population reduce financial viability

consequences.description: 768 rural hospitals at risk of closure, 315 at immediate risk
Increased travel distances (20+ miles for basic services) reduce care utilization
Higher maternal mortality and worse birth outcomes in rural areas
Shorter life expectancy and higher chronic disease mortality in rural populations

problems.title: Overwhelming Electronic Health Record Documentation Burden on Primary Care Physicians
problems.description: Primary care physicians spend nearly 2 hours on electronic health record (EHR) tasks for every hour of direct patient care, creating an unsustainable burden that drives burnout and reduces care quality. Clinicians spend 5.9 hours of an 11.4-hour workday in the EHR, with clerical and administrative tasks (documentation, order entry, billing, system security) accounting for 44.2% of EHR time (157 minutes daily). Inbox management consumes another 85 minutes (23.7%). Nearly 69% of PCPs feel that most EHR clerical tasks do not require a trained physician. The documentation burden has severe unintended consequences: each additional hour spent documenting results in a 7.1% reduction in the proportion of patients whose outside records are reviewed by their PCP, potentially compromising care coordination. EHR usability challenges include information scattered across multiple systems, forcing clinicians to spend extra time locating and synthesizing data, increasing the risk of overlooking critical information. While EHR use reduced work for administrative staff, the impact on clinician work has been more variable, with some tasks decreased while others—particularly charting and chronic disease management documentation—increased significantly.
problems.summary: PCPs spend 2 hours on EHR per hour of patient care, with 5.9 hours daily in EHR systems. 69% of PCPs feel EHR tasks don't require physician expertise, contributing significantly to burnout.

barriers: EHR vendor lock-in and interoperability issues

neglectedness.activeResearchers: High - ONC, AMA, EHR vendors actively working on solutions
neglectedness.fundingLevel: High - Significant investment in AI documentation tools

rootCauses.description: Regulatory and billing requirements mandate extensive documentation
Poor EHR usability and interface design not optimized for clinical workflow
Lack of interoperability forces manual data entry across systems
Defensive medicine and malpractice concerns drive over-documentation
Quality measure reporting requirements add documentation layers

consequences.description: Major contributor to physician burnout and career dissatisfaction
7.1% reduction in outside record review per additional hour of documentation
Reduced face-to-face time with patients during visits

problems.title: Chronic Underinvestment in Primary Care Undermining Healthcare System Effectiveness
problems.description: The United States chronically underinvests in primary care compared to other developed nations, with only 5-7% of total healthcare spending devoted to primary care versus 13-15% in other high-income countries. This underinvestment—spending only 5-7 cents of every healthcare dollar on primary care compared to the 13 cents average elsewhere—has contributed to poorer health outcomes despite the US spending more on healthcare than any other developed nation. The funding gap manifests in multiple ways: the 2025 Medicare Physician Fee Schedule reduced the conversion factor by 2.83% (from $33.29 to $32.35), continuing a trend of declining reimbursement that has seen physician reimbursement drop more than 33% since 2001 when adjusted for inflation. For smaller or independent practices, reduced revenue threatens sustainability, driving consolidation and reducing patient access to independent primary care. The fragility of fee-for-service payment became starkly evident during the pandemic, when FFS-dependent clinics faced financial disaster as patient volumes dropped, highlighting the need for more stable primary care financing models.
problems.summary: The US spends only 5-7% of healthcare dollars on primary care vs 13-15% in other nations. Medicare reimbursement has dropped 33% since 2001, threatening practice sustainability.

barriers: Specialist lobby resistance to payment redistribution

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Moderate - NAM, PCPCC, Commonwealth Fund advocating
neglectedness.fundingLevel: Low - Minimal political momentum for major reform

rootCauses.description: Medicare fee schedule historically undervalues cognitive services vs procedures
Specialist-dominated RVU committee (RUC) controls payment recommendations
Fee-for-service model incentivizes volume over value
Lack of political will to redistribute healthcare spending

consequences.description: Primary care practice closures and consolidation reducing patient choice

problems.title: Widespread Preventive Care Screening Gaps Creating Health Disparities
problems.description: Americans utilize preventive services at approximately half the recommended rates, with only 8% of US adults aged 35 and older receiving all high-priority appropriate clinical preventive services recommended for them. Nearly 5% of adults receive no recommended preventive services at all. These gaps manifest as severe health disparities: Black men have 25% higher heart disease mortality and 20% higher cancer mortality than non-Hispanic White men; Black women are 20% more likely to die from breast cancer and twice as likely to die from cervical cancer despite similar diagnosis rates. Groups least likely to receive preventive screening include those with limited or no health insurance, limited education, no regular source of care, and those subject to discrimination based on racial, ethnic, or sexual identity. Each barrier significantly impacts screening rates—lack of insurance, lack of regular care, and racial minority status each decrease colorectal cancer screening rates by 15%. The COVID-19 pandemic further exacerbated these gaps: wellness visits in 2022 remained below 2019 levels, and screening rates for blood pressure, cholesterol, blood glucose, and common cancers were significantly lower in 2021 versus 2019.
problems.summary: Only 8% of adults receive all recommended preventive services. Significant disparities exist by race, insurance status, and access, with minority populations experiencing 15-100% higher mortality from preventable conditions.

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Moderate - USPSTF, Healthy People 2030, CDC engaged
neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - ACA preventive care coverage mandates

consequences.description: Late-stage cancer diagnoses with lower survival rates

problems.title: Pervasive Patient Medication Non-Adherence Undermining Chronic Disease Management
problems.description: Medication non-adherence represents one of the most significant yet addressable challenges in primary care, with approximately 50% of patients with chronic illnesses not adhering to their prescribed medication regimens. In the US alone, poor adherence causes an estimated 125,000 deaths annually and underlies $100-300 billion in avoidable healthcare costs. Disease-specific non-adherence rates are alarming: 40-50% of diabetic patients don't follow medication regimens, with comparable figures for hypertensive patients. Poor adherence also causes 10% of all hospitalizations. The causes are multifactorial: illiteracy, polypharmacy (multiple medications), alcohol use, cultural issues, religious beliefs, cost barriers, and lack of knowledge about treatment options. Mental health issues including depression and cognitive impairment significantly contribute to non-adherence. Socioeconomic status determines access to health insurance and medication affordability—critical barriers for populations including those with low health literacy, the elderly, racial and ethnic minorities, and persons living in poverty. Primary non-adherence (never filling prescriptions) and non-persistence (stopping medications without medical advice) both contribute substantially to this crisis.
problems.summary: 50% of chronic disease patients don't adhere to medications, causing 125,000 deaths and $100-300 billion in avoidable costs annually. 40-50% of diabetic and hypertensive patients are non-adherent.

barriers: Medication costs remain prohibitive for many
Healthcare system not designed for ongoing engagement

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - Growing investment in adherence solutions

Depression and cognitive impairment affecting medication management

consequences.description: 125,000 preventable deaths annually in the US

problems.title: Care Coordination Fragmentation and Health Information Exchange Barriers
problems.description: Healthcare delivery in the US suffers from severe fragmentation, with patients receiving care from multiple disconnected providers who lack access to each other's clinical information. Recent data indicate that fewer than one in three hospitals can electronically find, send, receive, and integrate patient information from another provider. When patients experience care transitions such as discharges or referrals, most providers still rely on paper or fax, creating dangerous information gaps. Patients with chronic conditions are particularly vulnerable, seeing 15-23 caregivers within primary and secondary care annually, with communication often poor and not patient-centered. The health information exchange (HIE) landscape is notably fragmented, characterized by a patchwork of efforts at federal, state, community, enterprise, and EHR vendor levels. Rural settings experience more pronounced fragmentation due to greater diversity of EHR systems. This lack of interoperability has significant consequences: redundant testing costs $1.5 billion annually, adverse events from information gaps cost $1.9 billion, and clinicians spend $12 billion worth of time manually entering information. The 21st Century Cures Act and TEFCA aim to address these issues, but adoption remains incomplete.
problems.summary: Fewer than 1 in 3 hospitals can electronically exchange patient information. Fragmentation causes $1.5B in redundant testing, $1.9B in adverse events, and $12B in manual data entry annually.

barriers: Proprietary EHR systems with incompatible data formats

neglectedness.activeResearchers: High - ONC, HL7, FHIR community actively working
neglectedness.fundingLevel: High - Federal investment through Cures Act, TEFCA

rootCauses.description: Proprietary EHR systems designed without interoperability as priority
Lack of universal patient identifier hampers matching across systems
Competitive business models that benefit from data silos
Complex and varying state consent and privacy requirements
High implementation costs for smaller practices and hospitals

consequences.description: Redundant testing costing $1.5 billion annually
Adverse events from information gaps costing $1.9 billion annually
Clinicians spending $12 billion worth of time on manual data entry
Delayed care decisions due to missing outside information

problems.title: Telehealth Digital Divide Creating New Healthcare Access Inequities
problems.description: While the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated telehealth adoption, significant disparities in utilization persist, creating a new 'digital divide' in healthcare access. Systematic barriers prevent marginalized populations from accessing and using telehealth, with evidence showing that increased access disproportionately benefits individuals with fewer healthcare disadvantages. Practice-level factors including serving FQHC and rural populations are significantly associated with lower adoption of video-based telehealth. At least 17% of people in rural areas lack broadband internet access compared to 1% in urban areas, fundamentally limiting telehealth viability. Key barriers include technological issues, limited digital literacy, data security concerns, uncertainty about insurance coverage, and infrastructure limitations. Despite rapid pandemic adoption, telemedicine uptake among healthcare professionals remains inconsistent due to perceived risks including performance risks (visual restrictions), privacy risks (data security), and financial risks. Research gaps remain regarding whether telemedicine can fully replace in-person services without compromising care quality, particularly for underserved populations. The challenge of ensuring equitable access requires targeted efforts beyond simply expanding telehealth services.
problems.summary: 17% of rural residents lack broadband for telehealth vs 1% urban. Marginalized populations face systematic barriers to telehealth access, with disparities persisting despite expanded services.

barriers: Infrastructure investment required for broadband expansion

neglectedness.activeResearchers: Moderate - FCC, HRSA, telehealth organizations working on solutions
neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - Federal broadband and telehealth funding

problems.title: Complex Chronic Disease Management Challenges in Primary Care Settings
problems.description: Approximately one-third of all adults worldwide are diagnosed with multiple chronic conditions (MCCs), and managing these complex patients represents one of the most significant challenges in primary care. Chronic diseases account for more than two-thirds of all deaths in Europe and 75% of healthcare costs, yet primary care delivery systems struggle to provide effective ongoing management. Patients with chronic conditions are at higher risk of receiving poor care coordination, with their care divided between primary care providers and specialists across different organizations. Patients may see 15-23 caregivers annually, with communication often poor and not oriented at the individual patient. Treatment options for chronic conditions are typically disease-specific and fail to address the complexities of concurrent treatment of multiple conditions, particularly when behavioral health issues are involved. Rural health clinics and FQHCs face additional challenges with limited access to specialized care and provider shortages. Barriers include patient-level factors (difficulty with lifestyle changes, mental health issues, socioeconomic constraints), provider-level factors (emotional burden, time constraints), and system-level factors (lack of 24-hour services, fragmented delivery systems). The increasing prevalence combined with provider shortages represents one of healthcare's most critical threats.
problems.summary: One-third of adults have multiple chronic conditions, accounting for 75% of healthcare costs. Poor coordination across 15-23 caregivers annually and disease-specific treatments fail complex patients.

barriers: Disease-specific treatment guidelines not designed for multimorbidity
Fee-for-service doesn't support comprehensive care management
Workforce not trained in complexity management
Patient behavioral change is inherently difficult

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Moderate - CCM and PCMH models receive funding
